allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.rationale: Prednisone is first-line treatment. ABPA is an allergic/inflammatory response to Aspergillus, not a direct infection. IDSA/WHO guidelines recommend systemic corticosteroids.

herpes zoster.rationale: Prednisone reduces acute pain and speeds healing when combined with antivirals. Multiple RCTs support adjunctive use. Prevents postherpetic neuralgia.

leprosy.rationale: Prednisolone is essential for Type 1 and Type 2 leprosy reactions (erythema nodosum leprosum). WHO-recommended. Prevents nerve damage.

tuberculosis.rationale: Dexamethasone reduces mortality in TB meningitis by 30% (Thwaites 2004 NEJM). Also used in TB pericarditis. WHO-recommended adjunctive therapy.
tuberculosis.evidence: Thwaites et al. NEJM 2004, WHO TB guidelines

pulmonary tuberculosis.rationale: For pulmonary TB specifically, evidence is weaker than TB meningitis. Some use for severe inflammation. But CS can also reactivate latent TB (inverse indication conflict).
pulmonary tuberculosis.evidence: Mixed evidence, Cochrane review shows modest benefit

extrapulmonary tuberculosis.rationale: Strong evidence for TB meningitis, TB pericarditis, and TB uveitis. Dexamethasone reduces mortality in TB meningitis.

proctitis.rationale: Proctitis is often inflammatory (IBD-related, radiation-induced). Topical/oral corticosteroids are standard treatment for inflammatory proctitis.

cryptococcosis.rationale: Adjunctive dexamethasone was tested in cryptococcal meningitis (Day et al. NEJM 2014) - showed NO benefit and potentially harmful. IRIS treatment is the only CS indication.

fungal meningitis.rationale: May help with IRIS or inflammation, but not standard for fungal meningitis directly. Dexamethasone trial for cryptococcal meningitis was negative.

influenza.rationale: COVID-19 showed dexamethasone benefit for severe respiratory illness (RECOVERY trial), but for influenza specifically, WHO ADVISES AGAINST routine CS use. May increase mortality in severe influenza.
influenza.evidence: WHO advises against; Delaney et al. Crit Care 2016 meta-analysis

chronic hepatitis c.rationale: CS are immunosuppressive and can worsen viral replication in HCV. No clinical evidence supporting CS for HCV treatment.

hepatitis b.rationale: CS withdrawal can trigger severe HBV flares. CS increase HBV replication. Azathioprine→HBV reactivation is already an inverse indication. CS use is DANGEROUS.

cytomegalovirus infection.rationale: CS cause immunosuppression which WORSENS CMV. CS are a known risk factor for CMV reactivation. No therapeutic benefit.

herpes simplex virus infection.rationale: Systemic CS can worsen HSV infections by suppressing immune response. Only use is topical in combination with antivirals for HSV keratitis.

herpes simplex encephalitis.rationale: Adjunctive dexamethasone tested in GACHE trial (Kamei et al. 2005, Martinez-Torres et al. 2008) - some evidence for reducing edema, but primary treatment is acyclovir. Not standard.

rabies.rationale: No evidence CS help in rabies. Rabies is almost universally fatal once symptomatic. CS would worsen immunosuppression.

smallpox.rationale: CS are contraindicated in smallpox. Immunosuppression worsens viral replication. CDC explicitly warns against CS in smallpox/vaccinia.

aspergillosis.rationale: Invasive aspergillosis: CS are a RISK FACTOR (immunosuppression). ABPA: CS are treatment. Depends on type. Most aspergillosis predictions would be invasive → harmful.

poliomyelitis.rationale: No evidence for CS in polio. Historical use has been abandoned.

japanese encephalitis.rationale: Dexamethasone tested in Japanese encephalitis RCT (Kumar et al. Neurology 2010) - showed NO benefit. WHO does not recommend.

hepatitis a.rationale: No evidence for CS in hepatitis A. Self-limiting disease. CS immunosuppression is not indicated.

coccidioidomycosis.rationale: CS may help in coccidioidal meningitis (chronic inflammation), but can also worsen dissemination. Used cautiously in severe cases.

cryptococcal meningitis.rationale: Day et al. NEJM 2014 RCT showed dexamethasone INCREASED mortality in cryptococcal meningitis (OR 1.11). Only for IRIS.

chromomycosis.rationale: No evidence for CS in chromomycosis (fungal skin infection). Would worsen immunosuppression.

acquired immunodeficiency syndrome aids.rationale: CS used for PJP pneumonia in AIDS (prednisone reduces mortality). But CS generally dangerous in AIDS due to immunosuppression.
acquired immunodeficiency syndrome aids.evidence: For PJP only, not general AIDS

respiratory infection caused by pseudomo.rationale: Oral CS used in CF for anti-inflammatory effects, but risk of diabetes and growth impairment. Inhaled CS more appropriate.

sporotrichosis.rationale: No evidence for CS in sporotrichosis. Antifungals are standard treatment.

zygomycosis.rationale: CS are a RISK FACTOR for zygomycosis (mucormycosis). CS immunosuppression promotes fungal invasion.

visceral leishmaniasis caused by leishma.rationale: No evidence for CS in visceral leishmaniasis. Antimonials and amphotericin B are standard.

schistosomiasis.rationale: CS sometimes used for severe schistosomiasis (Katayama fever, neuroschistosomiasis) alongside praziquantel. Not standard monotherapy.

otitis media.rationale: Some evidence for CS as adjunctive in acute otitis media (reduce inflammation), but not standard practice. AAP guidelines do not recommend routine CS.

esophageal candidiasis.rationale: Inhaled/oral CS are a RISK FACTOR for esophageal candidiasis. CS suppress local immune defenses.

gastroenteritis.rationale: No evidence for CS in infectious gastroenteritis. Self-limiting. Supportive care only.
